title: Gensler Typeface used
content:
Hello if anyone has any clues, the typeface used in the Gensler identity as well as the body copy.

[http://www.gensler.com/#expertise](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115074612/http:/www.gensler.com/#expertise "http://www.gensler.com/#expertise")

I'm thinking the identity may have been a bit customized.

thoughts.

thanks.
author: Norman R

comments.content: The body looks like a (slightly modified?) [TheSans](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115074612/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/lucasfonts/thesans_basic/). The logo looks customized, perhaps from a Martin Majoor face, but I'm not sure.
Crap. Stewf and I posted at the same time, and I was WRONG!
Ah yes, I thought at first scala and thesans but I saw considerable differences in the detail upon closer view. Thanks Stephen great find with Kievit. dead on the money.

The Gensler identity isn't Kievit though. At least what I see has a different G. The 'e' is too open for the usual suspects (Helvetica/Univers/Akzidenz), and the G is wrong for Arial and Myriad. If there was a Letter Gothic Black it would be closer. Still looking..

- Mike Yanega

I almost looks like Kievit Bold with a modified 'G' (or a 'G' borrowed from, say, Akzidenz).

- Lex

Not sure if this is it, but Monotype's Slate seems quite close.

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115074612im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SlateTestGensler_6635.png)
I agree with Lex. It is Kievit with an alternative G for the logo.

Mike the Slate is very close and the G hands down is closer then what Kievet offers. I do think that the Gensler logo is a bit more condensed then if rendered by Slate. Kievit in that regards is closer.

OK, I'll go along with [AG as the G source](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115074612/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/akzidenz-grotesk-bq/bold/opentype-ps/329299/character/0047/CP2/1/) and Kievit for the rest. The closure on the Kievit G doesn't even make it a candidate with an added 'beard', so I think Lex's suggestion wins my vote.

- Mike Yanega
